title: Don Cameron (balloonist)
text:
Don Cameron MBE BSc MA MIEE D.Eng <a href="Royal%20Scottish%20Geographical%20Society">FRSGS</a> (born 1939) is a <a href="Scotland">Scottish</a> <a href="hot%20air%20balloon">balloonist</a>, and later founder of <a href="Cameron%20Balloons">Cameron Balloons</a>, the world's largest hot air balloon manufacturer. Don Cameron is one of the few <a href="aeronauts">aeronauts</a> to be awarded the <a href="Harmon%20Trophy">Harmon Trophy</a>, as the 'World's Outstanding Aviator' in 1999.
Early life and career.
Born in <a href="Glasgow">Glasgow</a> in 1939, Cameron went to <a href="Allan%20Glen%27s%20School">Allan Glen's School</a> and then went on to study <a href="aeronautical%20engineering">aeronautical engineering</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20Glasgow">University of Glasgow</a>, graduating in 1961. In 1963 he obtained a master's degree at <a href="Cornell%20University">Cornell</a>, <a href="United%20States">United States</a>. He then joined the <a href="Bristol%20Aeroplane%20Company">Bristol Aeroplane Company</a>.
Cameron developed Britain's first modern <a href="hot%20air%20balloon">hot air balloon</a> entitled "<a href="Bristol%20Belle">Bristol Belle</a>" which flew for the first time at <a href="Weston%20on%20the%20Green">Weston on the Green</a> in <a href="Oxfordshire">Oxfordshire</a>, <a href="England">England</a> on 9 July 1967. In 1968 Cameron and Leslie Goldsmith founded Omega Balloons which constructed ten balloons, before the company split into <a href="Cameron%20Balloons">Cameron Balloons</a> and Western Balloons in 1970.
<a href="Cameron%20Balloons">Cameron Balloons</a> of <a href="Bristol">Bristol</a>, England, was formed by Cameron in 1971 - five years after he constructed his first balloon. The new company was based in <a href="Cotham%2C%20Bristol">Cotham, Bristol</a> where a total of twenty nine balloons were made in the basement of the property. 1971 also saw Cameron build "Golden Eagle", a balloon designed specifically to fly across the <a href="Sahara">Sahara</a> to shoot a film for <a href="Jack%20Le%20Vien">Jack Le Vien</a>.
In 1978 his attempt to make the premier <a href="Atlantic">Atlantic</a> crossing by balloon ended when bad weather forced his heated <a href="helium">helium</a> balloon "Zanussi" down after a 2,000-mile flight from Canada. It was piloted by Cameron and Christopher Davey. They left <a href="St.%20John%27s%2C%20Newfoundland%20and%20Labrador">St. John's</a>, <a href="Newfoundland%20and%20Labrador">Newfoundland and Labrador</a> on 26 July 1978, covered 1,780 miles, and ditched on 30 July 1978 in the <a href="Bay%20of%20Biscay">Bay of Biscay</a> only 110 miles from <a href="France">France</a> after a tear developed in the balloon. The two planned a second attempt, but discarded their plans when the "<a href="Double%20Eagle%20II">Double Eagle II</a>" successfully made a <a href="transatlantic%20flight">transatlantic flight</a> three weeks later. Cameron and Davey were awarded the Gold Medal of the <a href="http%3A//royalaeroclub.co.uk/medals-and-awards.php%3Ftitle%3D%26amp%3Bid%3D54">Royal Aero Club</a> in the same year.
Never averse to technical challenges, Cameron went on to write computer programmes to design specially shaped balloons.
Cameron has received the gold, silver and bronze medals of the British <a href="Royal%20Aero%20Club">Royal Aero Club</a> for his ballooning achievements which include being the first man to cross the <a href="Sahara">Sahara</a> and the <a href="Alps">Alps</a> by hot-air balloon, and making the first flight between the UK and the former USSR in 1990.
<a href="Cameron%20Balloons">Cameron</a> <a href="Rozi%C3%A8re%20balloon">Rozière balloon</a>.
Labeled the "epitome of his achievement" Don Cameron redesigned the helium and hot-air balloon combination into the Cameron Roziere balloon which reached multiple milestones. In 1992 Don Cameron fulfilled his transatlantic dream by designing and flying his Roziere balloon from <a href="Bangor%2C%20Maine">Bangor, Maine</a>, <a href="United%20States">U.S.</a> to <a href="Portugal">Portugal</a>, taking second place in the first ever <a href="transatlantic%20balloon%20race">transatlantic balloon race</a>.
Taking off from <a href="South%20Korea">South Korea</a> and landing on 21 February 1995 in <a href="Leader%2C%20Saskatchewan">Leader, Saskatchewan</a>, flying a Cameron Roziere, <a href="Steve%20Fossett">Steve Fossett</a> became the first person to make a solo flight across the Pacific Ocean in a <a href="balloon%20%28aircraft%29">balloon</a>.
In 1999 a <a href="Cameron%20Balloons">Cameron Roziere balloon</a> R-650, named the <a href="Breitling%20Orbiter">Breitling Orbiter</a> 3, made the first non-stop flight round the world.
Don Cameron and <a href="Tim%20Cole%20%28balloonist%29">Tim Cole</a> designed and built the <a href="Spirit%20of%20Freedom%20%28balloon%29">Spirit of Freedom (balloon)</a> <a href="Rozi%C3%A8re%20balloon">Rozière balloon</a>. Cameron built the envelope and Cole the capsule. In 2002 solo <a href="aviator">aviator</a> <a href="Steve%20Fossett">Steve Fossett</a> flew the Spirit of Freedom to become the first successful around the world nonstop solo flight in any kind of aircraft. On 19 June 2002 the 10-story high balloon "Spirit of Freedom" lifted off from <a href="Northam%2C%20Western%20Australia">Northam, Western Australia</a> and landed in <a href="Queensland%2C%20Australia">Queensland, Australia</a> on 3 July 2002 (<a href="Independence%20Day%20%28United%20States%29">Independence Day</a> in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>). The solo flight circumnavigation lasted 13 days, 8 hours, 33 minutes (14 days 19 hours 50 minutes to landing) and covered 20,626.48 statute miles (33,195.10 km). They (Fossett & Spirit of Freedom) reached speeds of up to 322 kilometers (204 miles) per hour, and flew as high as 10,580 meters (34,700 feet).
